title: Gauss law - cylinder and 4 nC-per-m linear charge

content.question: An infinitely long line of charge has a uniform linear charge density of <math alttext="4.0 nanocoulombs per meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>nC/m</mtext></math>. The figure shows a cylindrical Gaussian surface of radius <math alttext="0.20 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> and length <math alttext="0.30 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.30</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> with its axis along the line of charge. What is the magnitude of the electric field at a distance of <math alttext="0.20 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.20</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> from the line of charge?

choices.label: <math alttext="220 newtons per coulomb" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>220</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/C</mtext></math>
<math alttext="360 newtons per coulomb" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>360</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/C</mtext></math>
<math alttext="540 newtons per coulomb" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>540</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/C</mtext></math>
<math alttext="900 newtons per coulomb" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>900</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/C</mtext></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="360 newtons per coulomb" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>360</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/C</mtext></math>
